you have to be creative living as a hiker in Indiana! Turkey Run is awesome in the winter time when no one is there.Browny County State Park and Morgan Monroe have wonderful hiking. If you're in Indianapolis, Fort Ben and Eagle Creek are amazing options. My boyfriend took me to Clifty Falls for my birthday last year and it is by far one of my favorite places to hike in Indiana!

I remember the carnage i saw in Daniel Boone National Forest. My boyfriend and I came up to what looked like an abandoned picnic. plates, food, bags of trash (enough for 10 people) just left there. these people decided they were finished and just left all of their supplies and trash. I am going to GSMNP for a birthday hike in a few days and I plan to take a couple of garbage bags with me.

WRITING.TEXT: I work at a boutique hotel and we have a pretty popular lounge that a lot of locals frequent. I had a man call me today saying he was thinking about proposing to his girlfriend in front of one of her favorite art pieces that we have at the hotel (they had their first date in said lounge). I helped him set up a little 'scavenger hunt' from the lounge to the art piece using our art cards we give to guests when they check in, the last one asking "will you marry me?" I love going out of my way for guests to do things like this. He was nervous about the whole idea but i reassured that the thought was incredibly sweet and she was lucky to spend the rest of her life with him. She said yes.

If you go to the [NPS website](https://www.nps.gov/grsm/planyourvisit/temproadclose.htm), they have a map of affected areas, and the extent of damage - they also have a list of all closed trails. I am actually going to Gatlinburg area for my birthday (mid February) and did a little research just so I could make the most of the trip after everything that has happened there. From what I read, Gatlinburg is recovering well and a small chunk on the park was affected, near the Chimney Tops trail.

Happy Birthday! I had the same feels when I turned 21 a few years ago. Even though the day is almost over, do something for YOU. it's your day to be selfish. I was so sad I didn't hear from family and only a few friends, so I packed up the pup and went for a day hike, something i knew would make me happy. You may have a handful of friends (assuming, going off personal experience) and that is OKAY. accept, own, and be proud of who you are and make today a celebration for just that.

Because it is NOT the highest point on any given road, it's the highest point on a continuous road. There are countless access roads that are NOT continuous, that reach much higher altitudes... like Mt. Evans
it is not the wrong word. do some research.
I never said Mt Evans road was a US highway. it is the highest vehicle accessible point in the United States, NOT a highway though.
Thank you. I put this here for you fuck wads to enjoy, not criticize my word choice Jesus fuck

Continuous meaning it doesn't have an 'end', like when you reach the top of Mt. Evans or any other access road. Trail Ridge Road is US Highway 34. It does not end when you reach the highest point, it continues on to Granby or Estes Park (depending on your direction).

Well I can understand! It is a very unusual spot, indeed. It is unmarked and there is absolutely no area to park your car (observation points are about 1/4 mile in each direction). You would not know this spot were anything special unless you had a RMNP map. I had to stop my car in the middle of the road, and keep an eye out for oncoming traffic, while i took this picture. It was about 80 degrees in Estes Park that day, and a mere 30 degrees at this spot.
there is indeed! i have been up there. Again, I am talking about the highest US HIGHWAY. I am fully aware of higher access roads

WRITING.TITLE: Hiking Boulder Mountain Park a few weeks ago.

WRITING.TEXT: Trail Ridge Road (U.S. 34) in Rocky Mountain National Park

both continuous and contiguous are correct terms. There are access roads higher than this point (approx 12,200 ft), that's why the key word is CONTINUOUS. No other US highway reaches this high of an altitude.

WRITING.TITLE: The highest point on any continuous US highway.
